title: surrey struck earthquake richter scale
story: The quake was felt at .am today in the same part of the UK where a swarm of tremors hit last summer - prompting warnings that more could be in store.Seismologist Davie Galloway of the British Geological Survey said the tremors were felt by  residents this morning.We have received several reports, mainly from the RH and RH postcode areas, Surrey and a few from Crawley, West Sussex, of this event being felt, he said.Typical reports described furniture shook very gently, everything moved forwards then backwards, a loud bang and strong impact and shake as though something had fallen on the house and general rumble that lasted for a couple of seconds.He said that the tremors were part of a natural earthquake and not linked to fracking or any other similar activity.Last year special monitoring equipment was installed to better understand what is happening beneath the surface of the area after  tremors were felt between April  to October .And the latest quake at Newdigate, near Gatwick Airport, may not be the last.Mr Galloway warned: It could be the start of another swarm, or it may just be a single event. Time will tell.With the past cluster or swarm we put it down to natural seismicity. We live on a dynamic planet.Plates move about all the time. Theyre bashing and moving away from each other.He said the UK was not on the edge of a plate so did not get hit by huge quakes, but stresses could still affect the rocks.There are roughly - earthquakes in Britain every year, but the vast majority are so small that no one notices them. However between - are over . magnitude which can be felt over a wider area.UK earthquakes, particularly in Scotland, are most often attributed to glacial rebound.Until about , years ago much of the north of the UK was covered by a thick layer of ice - which pushed the rocks down into the underlying mantle.These rocks have been slowly rising back up ever since the ice melted, causing occasional earthquakes in the process.The UK is also subject to tectonic stresses caused by the expansion of the Atlantic Ocean, which is slowly pushing the entire of Eurasia to the east, and from the northward motion of Africa, which is pushing into Europe from the south.

title: brexit vote latest theresa may brussels eu talks valentines day
story: The PM’s strategy was left in tatters on Valentines Day after Brexiteers abstained on her motion, leaving it to be defeated by  votes to .Furious Brexiteers said the motion would effectively rule out Britain leaving without a deal, and destroy our negotiating hand.But she vowed to push on ahead with her Brexit plans anyway, insisting that fighting to rip up the hated Northern Irish backstop was the only thing Parliament had said they wanted her to do so far.A Downing Street spokesperson blamed Jeremy Corbyn for putting partisan considerations ahead of the national interest and voting to make No Deal more likely.They also noted the concerns of Brexiteers who voted the motion down because they thought it would effectively take away the threat of leaving without a deal.No added: The motion on th January remains the only one the House of Commons has passed expressing what it does want – and that is legally binding changes to address concerns about the backstop.The Government will continue to pursue this with the EU to ensure we leave on time on th March.Scottish Secretary David Mundell insisted the defeat was not signicant in the long term. He added: The PM still has additional time to negotiate deal revisals Parliament said it needs.He predicted the second meaningful vote would come before the end of February, when MPs will be presented with a stark choice between backing Mrs Mays deal or crashing out of the EU without a deal.As the PM still did not have a deal for MPs to vote on today she put down a supposedly neutral motion instead.It said MPs welcomed the last votes in the House of Commons where they forced her to go back to Brussels, but also accepted that the House didnt want to leave without a deal - something Brexiteers said was ruling out a No Deal.Steve Baker insisted the PM must now fully endorse the Malthouse compromise as the only way forward.And Jacob Rees-Mogg added: The message tonight is that there is a majority for the Malthouse compromise, but the Government needs to work with its backbenchers, rather than against them.The PM appeared not to take the defeat seriously, and wasnt even on the front bench to hear the votes results come in.Shortly afterwards Jeremy Corbyn said the vote showed there was no majority for the Prime Ministers course of action for dealing with Brexit.And he blasted: The Government cannot keep on ignoring Parliament and heading for March  without a coherent plan.David Lammy stormed: This is a Valentine’s Day massacre for the government and a damning indictment of the Prime Minister’s Brexit plan.Tory Nick Boles said he hoped the penny will now drop with Prime Minister and her Chief Whip that the hardliners in the ERG want a  No Deal Brexit and will stop at nothing to get it.The defeat is likely to damage Mrs Mays confidence in talks with Brussels, as they will be sceptical as to whether she can secure a majority among her own MPs for any plan at all.Steve Barclay revealed the PM will fly to Brussels next week for fresh talks with Jean Claude Juncker in a last ditch attempt to persuade them not to derail her plans.And No insisted No Deal was still on the table - but the assurances werent enough for dozens of members of of the European Research Group.MAYS MOTION - The PMs motion was supposed to be a neutral one as she didnt have a deal ready to put to a vote.Instead she just said the House welcomed last weeks votes - accepting Sir Graham Bradys change to go back to Brussels and ask for more, and a non-binding amendment to rule out a No Deal Brexit.But it was slapped down when MPs said it would effectively rule out no deal, throwing a spanner in the works of the PMs plans.CORBYN AMENDMENT - SPEED UP THE CLOCK Labour frontbenchers have proposed an amendment aimed at stopping Theresa May from running down the clock on Brexit.It would force the Government to act within two weeks, either by holding another formal vote on the PMs deal or by declaring that the deal is now off the table permanently.SOUBRY AMENDMENT - COME CLEAN Tory pro-EU rebel Anna Soubry has teamed up with other Remainers to try and force ministers to publish the advice theyve had on a No Deal Brexit.If their amendment passed, Mrs May would have to publish the most recent official briefing document presented to Cabinet on the implications of a No Deal scenario.BLACKFORD AMENDMENT - WAIT TILL JUNE Ian Blackford, the SNPs Westminster leader, is calling for a delay of at least three months to the Brexit process.Mr Corbyn also faced embarrassment as  Labour MPs defied him to back a delay to Brexit.Rejecting the motion could also make the possibility of a soft Brexit more likelythe EU decide that theres more hope of passing the dealMrs May goes into serious talks with the Labour boss Jeremy Corbyn.Hes fighting for a customs union with the bloc but Mrs May has ruled it out, saying it wont deliver on Brexit properly.Shes still in talks with Mr Corbyn but doesnt want to risk splitting her own partyshe goes for a compromise deal.The PM is trying to get her deal through by changing the Northern Irish backstop, but shes facing a huge fight with the EU to get them to agree to legally binding changes.Yesterday she was forced to deny that she was trying to run down the clock on Brexit as one of her chief negotiators was overheard in a bar saying she would offer a huge delay or her own deal.Today the Dutch PM Mark Rutte warned that No Deal would have a devastating impact on the UK, as part of a push to get MPs to back the PMs deal.

title: brexit vote remain mps plot
story: A group of senior backbenchers pledged to act like an alternative Cabinet in order to stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal.Top Tory Oliver Letwin claimed the move was necessary to avoid the terrying prospect of a No Deal outcome.But their threat to delay Brexit will anger Leave-supporting MPs who want to see Brexit happen on March  as scheduled.Speaking in the Commons today, Sir Oliver laid out a plan to take No Deal off the table by extending the Article  process.He said the rebel group would push their proposal through in two weeksMrs May doesnt strike a deal by then.Sir Oliver admitted the proposal - where the Commons rather than the Government would be dictating the path of Brexit - would be unprecedented.He said: This is a remarkable condition for Parliament and Government and the country to find itself in.It has never previously been the practice for this house to have to take control and to direct Government policy by legislation, that is an extraordinary turn of events.When this house comes to that situation we will be as it were a Cabinet... we will actually be making a decision about the future of this country.We will have in effect to take on, for this period, for this purpose, the government of this country.Sir Oliver said the proposed vote on February  would be high noon for MPs who are desperate to rule out No Deal.Yvette Cooper, who is leading the revolt, told the Commons: If we dont do something sensible like this its like were just all living in a fantasy world in which we talk about alternative arrangements.We say something is going to come along and sort it out and it just doesnt.Its aswere all standing around admiring the finery of the Emperors new clothes and actually the Emperor is running around stark naked and everyone is laughing at us - or at least they would beit wasnt so sad.The amendment would see Mrs May being set a deadline of mid-March to sign off on a Brexit deal.If she failed, MPs would then vote to delay our leaving date, giving the Government more time to get a new agreement.The PM insists that No Deal must remain an option or her negotiating position will be fatally undermined.

title: brexit amendments explained mps vote
story: NewsBrexit vote amendments explained as Theresa May faces Valentines Day defeatTheresa May is facing another House of Commons showdown over Brexit. Her Valentines Day massacre was meant to be more of a love-in - but she faces defeat. Heres what to expectShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsShes not facing a total Valentines Day massacre - but it aint a love-in either "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is holding yet another round of Brexit votes from pm of Thursday  February. Just  days before Brexit, the PM has tabled a motion asking MPs to reiterate the support for her strategy that they expressed two weeks ago. But she faces defeat. And meanwhile MPs are tabling three amendments which would give them a chance to back a radically dferent approach instead. Its a re-run of two weeks ago, when MPs voted to reject the prospect of No Deal , and agreed to back the dealthe Irish border backstop can be fixed. The House of Commons showdown was originally billed a Valentines Day massacre where MPs could strip out core details of her plan for leaving the EU. Then it appeared MPs had backed off - in full knowledge that therell be another clash in two weeks from now. But she now faces a suprise defeat at the hands of Tory Brexiteers...  Heres how today works. Theresa May tables a statement. MPs then table amendments to it. Usually the amendments are the danger area. But Tory Brexiteers arent actually exercised about the amendments to her statement. Instead theyre cross about the statement itself - even though it has no legal force. It says: That this House reiterates its support for the approach to leaving the EU expressed by this House on  January . The problem is, the Commons agreed two things on January . One was to renegotiate the Irish backstop - a clause which could extend EU customs rules over the UK. Brexiteers are fine with this. The second was to reject the prospect of a No Deal Brexit. Brexiteers are not fine with this at all. Defeat on this motion wont have any legal force. But it will kneecap Theresa May in her talks with the EU, because it will show she doesnt have a united parliament behind her. Here are the  amendments she faces  Stop Tories running down the clock  Labours Jeremy Corbyn has an amendment that would stop the Prime Minister running down the clock. The bid would force the government to hold a full meaningful vote on the new Brexit deal by February  - or admit there is no longer a deal. If the government admitted there was no longer a deal, it would need to make a new statement on what happens next. It comes after ministers admitted MPs may only get their final meaningful vote a few days before the March  date of Brexit. Labour MPs fear that will blackmail them into choosing either Theresa Mays deal or a disastrous No Deal Brexit .  Delay the date of Brexit The SNPs Ian Blackford is seeking to extend the date of Brexit by no fewer than three months. This would have to be agreed with the EU, with whom extension talks would begin immediately.  Reveal secret No Deal briefing documents  Cross-party Remainers including Anna Soubry want to reveal the impact of no deal. Their amendment would instruct the government to publish the most recent official briefing document given to the Cabinet on the implications of No Deal on business and trade. The document would have to be published within seven days. Heres the threat coming soon Force the PM to rule out No Deal   NOTE: This amendment is not being laid THIS week - itll only be put forward towards the end of February. Labour MP Yvette Cooper is leading a fresh bid to rule out No Deal Brexit - after her previous attempt was defeated by MPs. Under her plan,there is still no Brexit deal by March , Prime Minister Theresa May must put no deal to a formal vote. MPs would then be able to vote to block a No Deal Brexit, choosing instead to extend the March  date of Brexit. Labours Brexit chief Sir Keir Starmer said the party will support Ms Cooper again, like they did two weeks ago. But hell have to convince some of the  Labour rebels who refused to back her last time to change their minds. A source said the amendment is being held back for now, because Tories clearly want one final opportunity to get a deal. “So it’s likely that it will be put to a vote at the end of the month, rather than now. At that stage, there are likely to be Tory resignations over it, the source said.  And here are the amendments that didnt make the cut The following amendments will not face a vote because they were not selected by Speaker John Bercow. Hold a ballot of MPs on the options  Remain-backing Tory grandee Ken Clarke is leading a bid for MPs to hold a vote on their preferences for the way forward. Under his plan, they would rank dferent options from  to X on a ballot paper - a highly unusual procedure. Any option could go on the ballot paperat least  MPs have backed it in advance. It comes days after the Tory MP was spotted having a curry with Commons Speaker John Bercow. We wouldnt possibly suggest the Speaker had something to say about this unusual ballot plan. Cancel the date of Brexit  SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil is leading a bid to cancel the  March date of Brexit. His amendment calls on the government to urgently revoke the Article  notication, which set a two-year countdown to our leaving the EU back in . Under EU rules, Article  cant be extended without getting permission from all  EU leaders. But it can be revoked completely on the UKs decision alone. Delay the date of Brexit Labours Geraint Davies is seeking to extend the date of Brexit with the option of a future public vote. Let MPs vote on a series of set options Cross-party Remainers led by Sarah Wollaston, the Tory GP and MP, want to gold a series of indicative votes on the shape of a future deal. The options would be:Theresa Mays deal as it stands A No Deal Brexit Theresa Mays deal with backstop changes A Canada-style deal Norway plus, staying in EFTA A second EU referendumHold a second EU referendum  Labour MP Roger Godsf is leading a fresh bid to force a second EU referendum. Under his plan, the March  Brexit date would be delayed while a second referendum is arranged. The referendum would then have three questions on the ballot paper - Theresa Mays deal, No Deal, or stay in the EU. The referendum would use the alternative vote system, where the least popular option is eliminated and second preferences are then re-allocated to decide the winner. Plaid Cymrus Jonathan Edwards is also leading a bid to hold a binding second referendum on EU membership. And Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable wants to delay the date of Brexit in order to hold a second EU referendum.

title: tories admit how much sneaked
story: NewsTories admit how much sneaked out cut will cost , pensionersMinisters have revealed the extent of cuts to pensions credit for elderly couplesShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMinisters have revealed how much a sneaked-out cut to pensions credit will cost pensioners - and how many will be affected.Pensions minister Guy Opperman announced the changes at .pm on the eve of the crunch meaningful vote on Theresa Mays Brexit deal last month. And in response to a Parliamentary Question tabled by the Labour Party, ministers have admitted the extent of the cut.Mr Opperman revealed , pensioners are set to lose an average of pound, a year as a result of no longer being eligible to claim Pension Credit. The changes from the Department of Work and Pensions will cut the numbers of people who are eligible for pension credit, which tops up the income of the poorest pensioners.   Couples where one is over the state pension age, currently  for both men and women, and one is not, will no longer get the benefit. Margaret Greenwood MP, Labour’s Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary, said: “Pensioners on low incomes should not have to lose out on Pension Credit just because their partner is younger than them. “Pensioner poverty is already on the rise and this change clearly breaks the Conservatives’ manesto pledge to protect pensioners’ benefits.“These are people on low incomes who not only may receive signicantly less support under Universal Credit , but also find that their younger partner could be subject to the unfair sanctions regime.“Labour will ensure that older people get the support they need to enjoy security and dignity in retirement.”   When the cut was announced, a DWP spokesman said: In , Parliament voted to modernise this system for new claims so only pensioners receive pension credit. Currently couple can move from working age benefits to pension age benefits when the older partner of the couple reaches state pensions age. The new rules mean this now takes place when the younger partner reaches state pension age too.

title: alesha macphail accused drank mad
story: NewsMum of Alesha MacPhail defendant called cops after spotting him half naked on night girl diedA -year-old boy, who cannot be named, has denied abducting, raping and murdering Alesha MacPhail and claims the crime was committed by Toni Louise McLachlanShareByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAlesha MacPhail suffered catastrophic injuries, the court heard "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCCTV footage shown to a jury shows the boy accused of Alesha MacPhails abduction, rape and murder leaving his house three times on the night she died. Giving evidence today, the accuseds mother said he was very drunk after drinking a bottle of wine and Mad Dog  at an exams party he held at their home. The woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons, said she argued with her son before going to bed on the night six-year-old Alesha disappeared. In the morning, the mum told the court she woke up to hear people searching for the young girl. She says she checked her CCTV, which she had installed because a relative with dementia was moving in, to seeAlesha could be spotted walking by. Instead, footage showed her son leaving and ing to the property on three occasions throughout the night. The -year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denies raping and murdering Alesha, as well as charges of child abduction and defeating the ends of justice.  He has lodged a special defence of incrimination stating Ms McLachlan, the partner of Aleshas dad Robert MacPhail, committed the crime. Alesha was reported missing by her grandmother, Angela King, at .am on July , and the child’s body was found at the site of an abandoned hotel on the Isle of Bute just before am that day. During the fourth day of proceedings, the mother of the accused gave evidence and told of how her son was clever, popular and well-liked in school. The accused had lots of friends, was good at maths and did parkour, she told the court. The mother of the accused said she was aware he had been smoking cannabis from the age of  but wasnt really that bothered about it. The accused’s mother told the court her son held a post-exam party on the night before Alesha disappeared. She said the pair had an argument on the night and her son was very drunk and angry.  The accused had drunk a bottle of wine and Mad Dog , she said. He was very angry because his -year-old sister had left the house with his friends. The last of his friends left around .am and he remained in the house, she said. She said she tried to get him to phone his sister before going to bed She also explained a video security system had been installed in the house because a family member with dementia was moving in. The jury were shown footage of them rowing at .am on  July,  - the night Alesha went missing. She and her son can be heard shouting and swearing at each other. The accused’s mother went to bed and said she was awoken at .am to shouting in the street as people looked for Alesha.  After checking the back garden she woke up her son and askedhe knew anything about Alesha’s disappearance. He replied no and went back to sleep. She then went out with her dog and joined the search where she met Alesha’s family and reassured them everything would be OK. The accused’s mum said she checked the CCTV in her home after hearing about Alesha’s disappearance. She sawthe accused ing home around am and was unaware he had left the house.She had been looking at the footage to seeAlesha had walked past the house.  She then went further back in the CCTV to discover her son left in the direction of Rothesay town and passed Robert MacPhail’s home. He ed from a dferent direction and had a shower. He left again wearing only shorts and carrying a T-Shirt and jumped over a wall. He did not have any shoes on. He came back seven minutes later. When she asked what he was doing he told her he did not know and was maybe looking for his mobile.She said she noticed his feet were dirty.  She confronted him about leaving the house and recalled him saying: I dont know, I mustve been looking for my phone. But when asked by advocate depute Iain McSporran QCthat puzzled her, she replied: Yes. The accused’s mother said she decided to phone the police about the CCTV after speaking to a friend. She told her friend her son had been out of the house when Alesha disappeared. She told the police about the CCTV because she thought it would eliminate him from their enquiries. The mum said: But I didn’t think he had actually done anything, it was more to help the police and eliminate him from their inquiries. The court was then shown footage from .am which she said she assumed was him leaving for the first time.  The court was then shown footage of a person arriving back at the house at .am. The mother of the accused said she assumes it is her son. He jumps over wall and enters rear of house. CCTV shows the bathroom light coming on. Footage shows the accused leaving the property again wearing just shorts. A third clip, which the accuseds mother said she was not aware of is shown to the court.It shows the accused ing to the house before sprinting out again with what looks like a torch. At :am he s home again, now walking. The trial continues.

The Queen, who has been receiving information from the organisation for much of its existence, met with a number of senior figures at the agencys former home near Londons King Cross. During her visit she joked about how her father King George VI would become frustrated with his scrambler phone, modied by GCHQ to make his calls secret. She also unveiled a plaque marking the anniversary, which contains a secret message. Can you crack the code    People have taken to social media to try and work out what it says. Heres a hint - look at the dots and dashes under some of the letters. The letters with dots spell out  Hundred Years, a nod to the special occasion. During her visit she met Alex Younger, chief of the Secret Intelligence Serviceand known as C, and Andrew Parker, director general of MI, the Secret Service. Mr Fleming added: Its clear to us all that the world is changing at an unprecedented rate. Its more interconnected than ever before.  And this is driving extraordinary opportunity, innovation and progress. Its also unleashing amazing complexity, uncertainty and risk. To keep up in this digital era - to optimise the potential of technologies like articial intelligence and quantum computing - we know we need to keep reinventing.  During her visit to the nondescript office block near Charing Cross station, the Queen met Ruth Bourne, , a former Bletchley Park code breaker. When the subject of scrambler phones - used to keep important conversations confidential - was mentioned, the Queen said: I remember my father had one, he used to get so cross when it didnt scramble. Took some time to heat up and then work. The machines used valves, today replaced by transistors, which needed time to warm up before the equipment would work.

story: NewsTeens head blows up like balloon after allergic reaction to hair dyeGeorgina Paraskeva claims she left with scorched and blistered skin after using a commercial hair dye product - so now uses coffee to colour her hair insteadShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  FEB NewsGeorgina Paraskeva believes the shocking reaction was to hair dye "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenager who claims he head swelled double its size using hair dye said she is now using coffee granules to colour her hair instead. Georgina Paraskevas said she was left looking like a monster after having an allergic reaction to what she said was Clairols Nice N Easy product last November. The -year-old claims the dye left her blind for two days and with a scorched scalp. Georgina, from Bristol, believes the reaction was to Paraphenylenediamine- a chemical commonly found in dark hair dyes. The online jewellery store owner is now speaking out about her terrying experience to ensure other people know of the potential risks and are aware of alternatives.  It was honestly the most horric experience of my le, Georgina said. Looking back at the pictures now is just horrible, my head doubled in size and I looked like a monster. It felt horrible and made me feel like I had zero confidence. I hated going out and felt really self-conscious and like people were staring at me. I made the conscious decision to stay inside as I hated going outside and feeling like people were looking at me, it was awful. Georgina was refreshing her hair colour using the Clairol black hair dye on November th - a product shed previously used with no problem - and claims her face and scalp suffered no adverse reaction.  However the following evening during a romantic meal with partner Josh Cox, , she said her head began to feel really hot and itchy. Over the next two days her face slowly started to balloon so panicked Georgina rang  where an operator advised taking an antihistamine to combat the swelling. After visiting her GP the following day and receiving cream to soothe her scorched and blistered skin her face continued to swell so much so her eyelids closed over leaving her unable to see. Georginas desperate mum bakery worker June Kellett, , rang for an ambulance on and was rushed to Southmead Hospital where she was hooked up to a drip. Georgina said: My whole family use Nice N Easy and Ive used it a few times before with no problems. That evening my head was absolutely fine but it was when I went out in the evening the following day my whole head was hot and seriously itchy.  I had blisters on my scalp and the skin on my hairline was really crispy. Later that week the swelling got worse and when my eyes started to swell up and I couldnt open them, thats when I felt really panicked. When I went to the hospital it felt like I had glass in my eyes and I went full-on blind. I couldnt see a thing for two days, it was horrible.  After being discharged from hospital with a antihistamine and steroid prescription, Georgina had to be cared for by her mum and partner as her vision was still affected for a few days. Three months on Georgina now avoids chemical hair dyes and uses coffee granules to tint her brunette locks. Georgina said: Ive started using natural remedies on my hair now and use coffee granules to colour it, it works really well. I want people to be aware that things like this can and do actually happen. A lot of people dont realise whats in hair dye and that it can be really dangerous, Im really lucky and super grateful that it didnt escalate. Since this happened Ive read up on it and I could have permanently lost my eyesight and its scary to see that people have died from it.  Im also a lot more cautious about the things I use on my skin and I just make sure I read everything and make sure it contains natural ingredients. A Clairol spokesperson said: The safety of the people who use our products is our first and most important priority, so we were very concerned to hear about Ms Paraskevas experience with Nicen Easy No Ammonia when we were first made aware of the incident last November. Unfortunately we were unable to get in touch with Ms Paraskeva at the time. Allergic reactions are very rare and hair colourants are extensively researched to ensure they are safe when used as directed and it is imperative patch tests are conducted at least  hours before each colouring occasion. Details of how to perform this test are included with each of our products to help minimise risk to consumers. We remain happy to discuss the matter with Ms Paraskeva should she wish to contact us on our customer helpline.

title: woman eyes taped shut after
story: NewsWoman had to have eyes TAPED shut after being left paralysed by disorderDelilah Corkery said she was struck by the neurological disease just as she thought she was recovering from her bronchitisShareCommentsByAlyce CollinsClaire Gilbody-Dickerson:,  FEB NewsThe fitness enthusiast said she felt like she lost pretty much her whole body "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fitness enthusiast was struck by a rare condition that left her having to tape her eyes shut. Former network engineer Delilah Corkery, , said she lost pretty much her whole body when she was struck by Guillain-Barreacute Syndromefollowing an initial bronchitis in February last year. The woman, from Calornia, USA, had hoped she was getting over the worst of that illness when she started to notice peculiar symptoms developing. In March , Delilah went out for a meal with some friends when she noticed that the food tasted bland and she couldnt actually distinguish any taste from what she ate.  Recollecting her experience, Delilah said: I was diagnosed with bronchitis two weeks prior to my first symptoms, and they say a respiratory illness can trigger GBS, said Delilah. I was out eating dinner and all the food tasted bland, like there was no taste. I also felt really hot. But when I got home that night, I washed my hands and the water was icy cold.  I then tried hot water and it was burning hot and touching anything metal felt like fire. The next day, I told my partner that I thought it was time to go to the hospital. I was there for seven hours sitting in the waiting room and when they finally saw me, it was for five minutes and they diagnosed me with vertigo, because I told them it was getting harder for me to walk, gave me some pills and sent me home.  But when she woke up the next day, Delilah was in excruciating pain and could no longer walk unaided. She was immediately sent to the hospital, where staff ran stroke tests, X-rays, MRI tests, blood tests and a spinal tap, which indicated a raised level of proteins, which is indicative of Guillain-Barr Syndrome . Delilah started on an IVIG treatment immediately, but by this time she had lost thein her legs, arms, face, including her eyes, and her bowel. The extent of Delilahs case meant she couldnt even blink but could still see, so she would have her eyes taped shut for eight hours every night for the following three months.  I lost my taste and feeling in my fingertips, then my legs and arms, then my torso, my ability to control when I went to the bathroom and my ability to eat, breathe and even blink. I was stuck, mentally aware but had no control, all in the space of five days. I lost pretty much my whole body, including my face. They put these bubble patches on my eyes during the day so that my eyes stayed moist, but they had to tape them shut at night. They had to give me sleeping medication and anti-anxiety medication every night because I felt paranoid. I was always wonderingsomeone  was in the room as I couldnt see anything. Delilah explained how she had to tape her eyes shut for eight hours every night, and do so for three months after she left rehab. I was intubated twice. Initially for five days, then they tried to take it out thinking I was breathing fine, but when they took it out, I felt like I was suffocating. I kept telling them I couldnt breathe but they just told me to relax until I yelled, and the doctor asked them to do a blood test. That was when they saw my CO levels were high, so they immediately put it back in for six more days. After three weeks in hospital, Delilah was then transferred to a rehabilitation centre where she spent almost a month regaining her strength. She then ed home at the end of April, after seven weeks of intense treatment.  Delilah spoke about the dficulty of going from being such a physically active person to not being able to blink or go to the toilet herself. I had to be moved by the nurses every few hours because I couldnt control anything. Going to the bathroom was the worst because GBS affected all my nerves, including my bowels. I had to be lted in and out of bed to use the toilet with an electronic lting device. I was refusing the pain medication they were giving me because it made me feel sleepy and loopy, so I was in a lot of pain. Just the slightest touch of my legs would be extremely painful. If they lted my leg it would just drop to the side. So finally, I askedthere was something  I could try and they gave me something called Lyrica. The day I started taking Lyrica, I was able to slightly lt my knee to my chest using my arms. It was the most amazing feeling and I sat there with my knee up to my chest for an hour.

story: NewsShocking message man received before job interview that really freaked him outA recruiter has revealed the very rude message he was sent by a candidate just days before a job interviewShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsA recruiter didnt know what to do after receiving a shocking text"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When applying for a new job, there are ious things you should avoid doing.You need to appear keen on the role, but there are of course limits to how far you should go to nab a position. Recruiter Graham Wynn says he was shocked to receive a message from a potential candidate, offering sexual favours infor a receptionist role.Graham, the founder of HR firm Superior People Recruitment, claims to have been sent the highly inappropriate message earlier this week. He shared screenshots of the bizarre conversation online. The conversation begins with Graham offering the unnamed woman a job interview.   He writes: I have received your resume and would like to arrange an interview at level ,  Collins St, Melbourne. If convenient could you please advise best day and time. Thank you. Graham. The woman replies, saying: Hi Graham. Is there anything I can do, specically to you, that would help me get the job  She adds a winking emoji to the end of her message. I put my phone down and walked away for five minutes, I asked people What do I do  My concern was, is this entrapment to see how I responded  With all this stuff going on. Graham admits he considered just ignoring the message, but colleagues convinced him that no response could be taken as a response. He explained: The rationale was because I didnt say no, I might be open to it. I spoke to a couple of people and they said the best thing to do is respond by saying This is not appropriate.  His actual response read: Refraining from ever sending text like that would help. In general showing unethical traits or an inappropriate sense of humour tends to detract from ones chances of getting a job. According to Graham hes heard nothing back from the woman since - and hes definitely not putting her forward for the job. But this wasnt the first time hes been offered a bribe. story: NewsMH flight mystery was definitely murder-suicide claims aviation expertFormer air crash investigator Larry Vance said the Malaysian Airline plane was stolen by either the pilot or co-pilot in what he called a criminal eventShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video what-really-happened-to-mh-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Canadian aviation expert claims Malaysian Airline flight MH was crashed deliberately in a murder-suicide.Former air crash investigator Larry Vance said he was certain that either Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah or co-pilot Fariq Abdul Hamid stole the plane in what he termed a criminal event.The fateful flight took off from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March ,  but vanished without a trace with  crew and passengers on board.Vance, formerly of the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, told CBC News: It’s not an accident. This was planned and conducted, carried out by one inidual who had control of the aeroplane via his job to have control of the plane. He claimed that the pilot or co-pilot made the decision to take it to a remote part of the ocean and make it disappear forever.   After studying the crash debris, Vance claims the sections of the flap system were positioned downwards and that the plane entered the water at a low speed. He said: I believe with  percent certainty that the aeroplane entered the water in a controlled ditching with the flaps extended. This indicates the pilot had deliberately crashed the aircraft into the sea, he claims. We would call that a controlling ditching into the water, Vance told  Minutes Australia in an interview. The only way that could happen issomeone was flying the aeroplane. In particular,somebody selected the flaps to be in the extended position.  He added: If the flaps were down, then somebody would have had to have put them down, and they had to have put them down intentionally. Vance has put forward the theory in his book MH Mystery Solved which he spent  months researching. The investigator was not part of the official investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau Bureau but teaches the details of the incident to students.   Vances theory has not been universally accepted by those connected to the case. Martin Dolan, former head of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, there was not enough evidence to support a murder-suicide conclusion - adding that it was speculation that the flap system was positioned downwards. The evidence is not yet sufficient to draw as firm a conclusion as you appear to have done, he told Minutes.  MHs disappearance has resulted in numerous theories as to its eventual fate, including some which say the plane was switched on autopilot and ran out of fuel.Indonesian fisherman Rusli Khusmin, , claims his crew witnessed the disaster while on an expedition off the coast of northern Sumatra, Indonesia.He stated that the stricken plane emitted black smoke as it plunged into the Straight of Malacca in .  Speaking at a press conference in Kuala Lumpur, he said: I saw the plane moving from left to right like a broken kite. There was no noise, just black smoke as a result of fires before it crashed into the water. story: Recent recruit Mark Connolly believes Dundee United added real quality in the January transfer window but insist there is no “them and us” between the new arrivals and the players who were already on the books.The former Crawley Town and Kilmarnock defender says the aim of getting the Tangerines back to where they belong in the Premiership will be achieved through a group effort.The experienced Irishman has turned in two highly-impressive performances against Morton and St Mirren since his deadline-day arrival.And fellow-new men like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Cammy Smith have also shone in those victories.The -year-old is quick to point out that, while the spotlight has been on them, the team as a whole has earned the recent success.“Dundee United is a very big club and, unfortunately, we’re in the league where we don’t want to be,” he said.“That’s the reason why myself and quite a few others have come in to help the boys already here and move up and get back to where we should be.“We are here to add to the players already here because, on top of all the boys who’ve just come in, we have very good players here.“We’ve only trained a few times together but you can see the quality that’s here and I think the manager has added just that bit more bite to help the football club.”Connolly realises the changes manager Robbie Neilson made in January means it is going to take a while for the players to get to know each other’s games inside out.It’s a process, though, that has been done while winning games and, under Neilson, he believes that can continue to be the case.“There have been a lot of changes but we are professional enough to handle that.“Sometimes it’s an excuseyou don’t start well and say we’re a new team and will need time to gel.“We don’t have the time to do that and we have brought in players who have experience and quality.“The manager has been dferent class – he’s a top-quality manager and deserves to be in the top league.“Myself, the new boys and the boys already here can help him get there.”Performances like the weekend Scottish Cup success at the Buddies will help.Connolly feels it’s one that will have had others sitting up and taking notice.“First-half we did what we know we can do. Being on the pitch it certainly felt it could have been a lot more than - at the break.“We dominated the game and that gives you a bit of confidence, especially playing against a Premiership team.“Second half we knew St Mirren were going to come out and have a bit more about them.“They did, but we were dealing with it without any real problems.“Unfortunately for us, Calum Butcher got sent off when it was a - tackle in midfield and could have just been a yellow card.“But he got sent off and then we showed the character to stick in and win the game.“We were playing against a team from the level above us for about  minutes with  men. We rolled our sleeves up and got the result we deserved.”

title: far travelled dundee star ryan mcgowan says scots footballers are luckier than they think
story: Far-travelled Ryan McGowan believes Scottish footballers don’t realise how lucky they are as they make their way in the game without having to give up their home comforts.When the -year-old signed for Dundee on loan from Bradford City at the end of last month, it took his tally of clubs in a -year senior career to .And having turned out for outfits in his native Australia, Scotland, China, the United Arab Emirates and England during that period, he’s clocked up more air miles that your average long-haul airline pilot.Having always known he’d have to travel round the world to make a career in football, the Socceroo believes it’s made him more open to hop from one country to another.That, he’s learned, is in contrast to many of the friends he’s made here in Scotland.“Scottish kids probably don’t realise how lucky they are. They’ve got something like  full-time clubs within a three-hour drive of where they’ve grown up,” he said.“When I was growing up in Adelaide, we had one team and then it was a two-hour flight to the next closest.“Soyou weren’t good enough for that team, you had to work harder and be prepared to sht around.“I know boys here who only want to play for teams in or near Edinburgh – and they can.“Scottish boys are very lucky to have so many clubs and opportunities without having to move.”While he’s no regrets about his nomadic career, McGowan admits the chance to hang around in one place for a prolonged period is growing more attractive.Particularlythat place is here in Scotland, the country he regards as his adopted home.“I do sometimes think I’d love to sign a two or three-year contract somewhere again,” he added.“I would have probably have loved to have stayed on at Hearts for a couple of more seasons and I was enjoying my time at United when I was there but bids came in and were accepted.“And having an Australian passport does open doors in Asia, which is why I’ve ended up there a few times.”If the chance arises to stay at Dundee long-term, he admits it’s something he will give serious thought.He has not, and will not, look that far ahead until he’s helped the Dark Blues out of their current predicament.“A couple of weeks ago moving to Dundee hadn’t even come onto my horizon. Everything has happened quickly and I just want to make sure that, first and foremost, we stay in this league.“When the summer comes,an opportunity arises to stay I will definitely consider it but there is a lot of work to be done between now and then.”He is confident by the end of the season Dundee will be safe.“It’s been really good so far. They are a great bunch of boys and they have made me feel really welcome in the dressing-room.“I’ve kicked most of them when I was playing here in seasons gone by so I know most of them.“There’s a good manager in Jim McIntyre to work under as well. I’m showing my age here but I’ve actually played against him when I was a young player on loan at Ayr from Hearts.“He was coming to the end of his career then and later I played against a couple of his teams once he’d become a manager.“I’m quite close with a couple of players who have played under him and they spoke highly of him and that was more of a factor in coming here.“Having played across the road I also knew how big a club Dundee is. It’s a good club, in a dficult position at the minute but definitely one we can get out of.”

title: george cran dundee are in a far better place now than when jim mcintyre arrived
story: Almost four months into his reign as Dundee manager, Jim McIntyre won’t look back on his first match in charge with too much fondness.However, he might just do so with a great deal more satisfaction with how his squad has shaped up in the time since.Despite only picking up two wins and six draws in the  matches under McIntyre, there’s a growing sense of optimism at Dens Park after some encouraging displays since the January transfer window.The opposite can be said of Saturday’s opponents Livingston, the side the Dark Blues faced in Jim’s debut in the dugout.After a lightning-fast start to theirto the Premiership – which peaked with that - thumping of Dundee back in October – Livi’s form has slipped off a clf with last Wednesday’s - draw at Hearts bringing a five-game losing streak to an end.Since leaving Dundee gaffer Jim in no doubt how big a job he had on his hands with that - success at the Tony Macaroni Arena, Gary Holt’s side have only picked up three victories and none since the middle of December.That’s seen them slip from a high of second spot with  points from their first eight games down to ninth with just  picked up from the following  matches.And, though the gap between the sides hasn’t shrunk in those four months, the feeling around both clubs right now couldn’t be more dferent.A massive part of that from Dundee’s point of view is the complete overhaul of the playing squad in the winter transfer window.In fact, there’s a fair chance there won’t be any of the players who featured in the - defeat the last time the Dark Blues travelled to West Lothian this time around.Only three of the  used by Jim that day remain at the club – Elliott Parish, Cammy Kerr and Kenny Miller.Of those, only Miller looks like he could be given a start this time around but even he has a fair bit of competition to overcome with Andrew Nelson on the goal trail and Craig Curran preferred by the manager to lead the line in every match since he arrived at the club at the start of January.A missed penalty in stoppage time in their last run-out won’t have helped veteran Miller’s cause either.Meanwhile, Parish hasn’t featured since that - thumping and doesn’t look like dislodging Seny Dieng as first choice any time soon.The nature of the goals that day, with all four from set-pieces, no doubt led the manager to question his defenders.Parish quickly paid the price by dropping to the bench while three of the back four have been moved on.Andy Boyle is now at Ross County, Ryan Inniss was sent back to Crystal Palace after a nightmare at Palmerston in the Scottish Cup and Calvin Miller has also dropped to the Championship, being picked up by Ayr United on loan from Celtic.Kerr was right-back in October but he’s seen his place taken by new signing James Horsfield in recent games.The former Manchester City kid has looked assured in Kerr’s place and will take some shting before Saturday.The rest of the team have since been shown the exit door – Glen Kamara, Kharl Madianga, Lewis Spence, Sofien Moussa, Benjy Kallman, Roarie Deacon and Adil Nabi have all moved on.Even the side that drew - with Livi at Dens on Boxing Day will be unrecognisable to the one running out this weekend.Whatever side he opts for, Jim knows his team are in a far better place than when he took over – now they have to prove that by getting points on the board.

story: St Mirren defender Paul McGinn will face no further punishment after his arm caught Dundee United’s Cammy Smith in the face during the clubs’ Scottish Cup fth round tie on Saturday.The Buddies full-back was cautioned after his elbow made contact with his former Paisley team-mate early in the second half as St Mirren crashed out of the cup - to Robbie Neilson’s Championship outfit.Referee Willie Collum was just yards away from the collision and only deemed the offence worthy of a yellow card.Even though the foul was seen by the referee, under SFA rules compliance officer Clare Whyte could have issued a notice of complaint to the former Dundee full-back had she decided the incident was “exceptional in nature”.A  of three former referees would also have to have given their unanimous agreement McGinn deserved to be sent off for Whyte to proceed with a notice of complaint but it has been decided there was not enough evidence.

title: tom duthie this time the renewed hope at dundee united might not be a false dawn
story: For the first time in a long time, perhaps even since the dark days of relegation in , there is strong reason for optimism at Dundee United.The one thing that should be stressed about that immediately is it’s still early days.Robbie Neilson’s rebuilt team is only two games in and that means there is some way to go before we can confirm things are definitely on the up at Tannadice.And the truth is that will only come with promotion back to the Premiership.It must also be said there have been other  dawns over the past three years.The arrival of Ray McKinnon and then Csaba Laslo as managers brought hope and even early promise that, after the disastrous   campaign, things were being turned around.In fairness to McKinnon in particular, had he been handed the kind of budget that was made available to the current team boss in the January transfer window, the major problems at the club might well have been sorted and the Tangerines could have been back in the top flight already.Unfortunately for him, those in the boardroom when he was in charge were unable to provide the kind of cash for signings new American owner Mark Ogren has.That, incidentally, is not a criticism of the previous regimes, just an unfortunate fact.Neilson has been lucky he’s got an owner with dollars to spend and the indications so far suggest that owner is just as fortunate that he has a manager who knows how to spend it wisely.Ogren can also consider himself blessed his predecessor in the chairman’s seat at Tannadice, Mike Martin, found not just a good manager, but one who through being out of the game for a period, had taken the time to look at United and form a clear picture of what was needed.Because one thing that’s obvious about the signings made is all have been part of a jigsaw in the manager’s mind.January  didn’t just come round and see Neilson turn his thoughts to what was available. He’d done his homework and, equally importantly, worked out exactly where his squad needed strengthening.That means the right players for the right positions have been found, or so it seems.That’s produced victories over Morton and St Mirren that have lted spirits among Arabs. Rightly so, because both outings have seen impressive work.Of course, with most of those brought in lacking match fitness – that’s usually the major issue with January signings – the good football, has mostly come in the first hour.Players who’ve not had a lot of game time have tired, particularly when reduced to  men at St Mirren. They’ve then shown their ability to manage matches.What the manager also looks to have done well is identy those already in his squad who were good enough to be part of his plans.For all new boys like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Mark Connolly have deserved the praise they’ve received for their first couple of performances, attackers Pavol Safranko and Nicky Clark have shown they remain big players.After a run of just two goals in nine games, Safranko has found his scoring touch with one in each of the last two outings and has looked the lethal striker he did when he first arrived on loan from Aalborg.Now he’s finally got fully fit, Clark also looks dangerous and there’s no doubt both have benefited from having better players round them in the last two outings.For Neilson and his players the trick is now to keep the good work going. The good news for United fans is, this time, that might just happen.

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: revealed true scale of lifebelt vandalism in aberdeen
story: Almost half the safety equipment along a two-mile stretch at the River Dee in Aberdeen has been vandalised, the Evening Express can reveal today.We examined the le rings after schoolgirls had to be rescued from the water when their boat capsized near Victoria Bridge at the weekend.It later emerged the rope on the le-saving gear had been cut, hampering the rescue.Since , all le rings owned by Aberdeen City Council – including those at Aberdeen Beach, Rivers Dee and Don, and Seaton Park – should be inspected on a twice-weekly basis.Video: Operation to rescue school girls on River Dee hampered after le saving equipment vandalised" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local video-operation-to-rescue-school-girls-on-river-dee-hampered-after-le-saving-equipment-vandalised embed # secretXiqjY" data-secret"XiqjY" width"" "" title"#Video: Operation to rescue school girls on River Dee hampered after le saving equipment vandalised# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Our reporters checked each lebelt on both sides of the river, from Victoria Bridge to the Bridge of Dee at Garthdee, and discovered  of the  showed some sign of vandalism.This included a missing throw-line, graffiti and broken lock ties, which are the plastic bindings meant to keep the equipment locked away in their red casings and to let the public know it is safe to use in an emergency.In some cases, the throw-line appears frayed, as though an attempt had been made to cut it, and in another a cut rope had been tied back together.Council officers inspect the lebelts twice weekly, making sure signs are visible for members of the public to callthey notice any damage on the devices.The checks include making sure the throw-line is between - metres long and that the ring is still buoyant.Figures from Aberdeen City Council show there is an ongoing issue with damaged lebelts and ropes. City-wide, since , there were  lebelts and  ropes replaced. This year, four lebelts and  ropes were installed or swapped out for new ones.When told of our findings, Ian Yuill, councillor for Airyhall, Broomhill and Garthdee, said: “This is alarming and hugely worrying. The le safety rings are there to save lives.“Just how stupid or nasty does someone have to be to deliberately put lives at risk by vandalising a le safety ring ”Yvonne Allan, councillor for Torry and Ferryhill, said: “I am really concerned about what they are doing as it may be their lives that need saving next, or even their family members.”Councillor Catriona Mackenzie, councillor for Torry and Ferryhill, said: “Vandalism of this equipment is beyond stupid and irresponsible, butthat has been an ongoing issue, then the city council should have identied it and worked with partner organisations to prevent further spates.“We cannot get complacent, especially when over the weekend, in an emergency situation, one of these lebelts could not be used because of damage that hadn’t been repaired. The Evening Express’ work to investigate the extent of this problem is commendable.”A council spokeswoman said: “The lebelts along the rivers and beach are inspected twice a week for any faults which do not adhere to regulations, and action is taken to remedy any faults found. The inspections along the beach front are increased to every day during the summer, due to the increased numbers of people using the area.“However, we cannot be everywhere at all times, and we ask peoplethey see anything amiss to report any faults to us on   , andthey witness any vandalism to phone the police.“We strongly advise people not to tamper with the boxes and lebelts, as the equipment can literally save lives at a time when every second counts,someone is in our fast-flowing rivers or the sea which also has strong undercurrents.“The inspection we carried out to these lebelts last week did not show faults so we thank the Evening Express for bringing it to our attention and this led to additional inspections which found at least  security seals had been damaged.“We will be reporting the damage to the police.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby
