John Bercow, the Speaker, will decide which ones will be debated and voted on this evening.Labour has tabled a proposal, which would require the Government to either put its deal to a vote by February  or allow Parliament to take control of the process.Its Shadow Brexit Secretary, Keir Starmer - who on Wednesday had "frank and serious" talks with David Lidington, the PMrsquos de facto deputy - said Labour was committed to preventing Mrs May from pursuing a "reckless" policy of running down the clock so MPs were faced with a choice between her deal or no-deal with just days to go to exit day.The SNP tabled an amendment requiring the UK Government to begin immediate negotiations with the European Council to extend Article  by no less than three months.:Ian Blackford accuses Theresa May of rewriting the history books over BrexitIan Blackford, the party leader at Westminster, said: ldquoThe UK Government must stop running down the clock and put the brakes on Brexit before we are dragged off the clf-edge with catastrophic damage to jobs, living standards and the economy.Other amendments include one tabled by Ken Clarke, the former Tory Chancellor, calling for votes on ious Brexit options and one from the SNPrsquos Angus MacNeil to scrap the Article  process altogether.While todayrsquos vote will be an important indicator of Parliamentrsquos mood, any successful amendment will not be legally binding on the Government.In contrast, a promised next-steps vote on February  is being described as ldquoHigh Noon as it is when a new amendment, drawn up by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper, will be tabled, stipulatingthere were no deal by mid-March, MPs would either vote to agree a no-deal Brexit or to require the PM to seek an extension of Article .A similar move was defeated in January but the new version appears to be gaining more support and could even be backed by Cabinet ministers, who would resign to do so. One Whitehall insider said: ldquoIt looks like it could get through this time.

title: wouldnt-you-love-to-see-the-end-of-st-valentines-day
story: Herersquos how it runs yoursquove woken up to a Hallmark card from which you can almost smell the cheesethen later tonight you and your partner will be squeezed into a tiny corner table at a restaurant where you will eat a very average dinner while all the time wishing Richard Curtis had supplied you with a script. You see, while love is indeed a many splendoured thing, it can dry up, unlike the labradoodle puppyrsquos pee in the hall, so often your default discussion piece these days.Thankfully, the closeness of the couple at the next table is such you can distract yourself with their delightfully inane conversation thatrsquos as surreal as a Bros twinsrsquo argument ndash which makes your own puppy talk seem almost Stephen Fry-clever by comparison. But the distraction doesnrsquot last. Before you know it yoursquore stupid enough to check your smart phone a dozen times. Instead of staring into limpid eyes yoursquore looking at someone looking at you as though yoursquore a flatmate whorsquos late with the rent. What a brilliant wake-up call!Yet, herersquos what pushes your coupling wonderfully over the edge. You check into the city centre hotel for the night, order a bottle of fizz and later discover the night cost as much as thebill for Derek Mackayrsquos public speaking lessons. Now yoursquore one of the m Brits out there who celebrate VD ndash but wonderitrsquos really worth it  Yoursquore both thinking:love is blind whatrsquos the point of this expensive lingerie Tomorrow, reality will dawn. The relationship may still have its Hepburn-Tracy trace elements but theyrsquore fading like sun-exposed celluloid. The previous night had revealed a huge gap between expectations and reality. This is a relationship screaming out for Relate ndash or a orce lawyer ndash who will delight in the new business. Everybody wins!Read more: Valentinersquos Day: Scotlandrsquos  most romantic spotsYet, itrsquos not just long-term partners who can learn from the special day. The construct is intensely valuable for youngsters. Just as the end of a goldfishrsquos le teaches little people about death, VD slaps the tiny face with the realisation love is often unrequited. Itrsquos all very well Albert Camus claiming ldquoI know of only one duty, and that is to love but whatthe boy girl in P thinks yoursquore as appealing as broccoli Yet, should we be surprised Valentinersquos Day so often signals disaster ahead  Depending on research, the occasion emerged either from a bizarre Roman fertility ceremony, whereby men would sacrice dogs and goats, skin them, then whip women with the hides . Or, much later, Emperor Claudius II had two men named Valentine executed on February , who became martyrs.Perhaps the celebration could be based on young Valentinus. Awaiting death for his Christian beliefs, he wrote a love note to a jailerrsquos blind daughter, signed ldquoFrom your Valentine.Whichever, itrsquos clear each involved humiliation ndash and worse. Thankfully, this theme has continued. Valentinersquos Day is either a terric reminder yoursquore not in a relationship, that you used to bein a relationship, or yoursquorein a relationship and perhaps shouldnrsquot be.Yes, some will say they recall the thrill of receiving the unsigned, curious card. But try that at work today and HR could well be talking to you about sexual harassment.Read more: The Great Escape isnrsquot a film, itrsquos a lesson in survivalNow, you may be thinking this to be a rather dark take on the most romantic day, emerging from the mind of a desperate singleton just a click away from ordering up an Eastern European internet bride. Well, that day may indeed be close. However, who can deny therersquos too much of the Steve Wright Sunday-Morning-Love -Songs smugness around  Does Steve factor in those confined to an MS dinner for one American psychologist Melissa Orlov writes: ldquoThere are probably couples out there that think Valentinersquos is a great holiday. But I donrsquot see them in my marriage consulting practice. Instead, right around February  I inevitably start fielding calls about hopelessness and disappointment. In recent times, one crisis call centre in the United States reported a  per cent rise in helpline calls on Love Day.But donrsquot think Irsquom a Byron-hating, heartless killjoy. Irsquove watched Four Weddings at least five times, I love anything by Nora Ephron, Some Like It Hot, Breakfast At Tfanyrsquos and Roman Holiday .Teary teenage eyes were swtly, secretly wiped at when Love Story cancered out Ali McGraw and when Dr Zhivago gave Omar Shar a heart attack as he jumped off the tram in pursuit of Julie Christie.My favourite record is Eltonrsquos Your Song. The reality is Irsquom right with Shelley when he wrote: ldquoNothing in the world is single. All things by a law ine. In one spirit meet and mingle.But Valentinersquos Day  Celebrate ityou can, butyou have to declare undying love then do it quietly. Preferably in October.

title: model-of-maid-of-the-loch-unveiled-in-its-new-home
story: A hand-made replica of the Maid of the Loch paddle-steamer, painstakingly fashioned by Lachie Stewart, a lelong model-maker, was unveiled at its new home, in a gleaming new display case at the Loch Lomond Shores mall.The : large-scale has been moved from the paddle steamer itself, and is said to provide a true likeness from when the Maid was in commission. Its decks are crowded with small figures representing passengers.Mr Stewart said: ldquoI believe the scale of the ship works very well - it is large enough to add the small figures and they really make the Maid come alive. I hope seeing it encourages viewers to make a donation and help this wonderful vessel to sail again on the waters of Loch Lomond.John Beveridge, Director of the Loch Lomond Steamship Company, said yesterday: ldquoThe generous gt donated by Lachie has grabbed the attention of many of our visitors, both old and young, through its incredible detail and large-scale size.ldquoWersquore now sharing its charming features with our close neighbours at Loch Lomond Shores, to show what a typical day of sailing onboard Maid of the Loch would be like. We hope this inspires visitors to the Shores to climb onboard the cause and envision the Maid as a sailing paddle steamer once again for the enjoyment of everyone, today and for future generations.The Maid currently operates as a static tourist attraction and hopes to gain industrial museum status for the ship and steam slipway as a growing number of artefacts are collected and restored to working order.The paddle steamer will reopen in Easter for open season with the Balloch Steam Slipways ldquoIn Steam at the weekends. This will show the steam engine and gearing system in operation, with audio-visuals describing how the slipway pulls the Maid out of the water.A pound, capital grant funding award by the Scottish Government to the Maid of the Loch was confirmed last December, meaning that the goal of ing the ship to sail lives on.

title: scottish-government-to-overhaul-hr-operation-after-alex-salmond-case
story: SNP ministers are spending an initial pound, hiring consultants to help draw up a ldquoproposed HR Transformation Strategy for their troubled People Directorate.Edinburgh-based PA Consulting Group will now work on an analysis of options, targets, a ldquotransformation roadmap, an outline business case and a detailed business case.:Business diary of Nicola Sturgeons top aide records gym class but not Alex Salmond meetingThe work also covers ldquoHR best practice, suggesting shortcomings in the current set-up need to be addressed.The contract ndash awarded without being publicly advertised under an expedited system ndash comes just a month after the failure in Mr Salmondrsquos case.The former First Minister won a judicial review hearing at the Court of Session over the handling of the governmentrsquos investigation into alleged sexual misconduct complaints.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondMinisters admitted the probe was unfair, unlawful and tainted by apparent bias when it emerged the chief investigator had prior contact with the two complainers, which rendered the process invalid and left taxpayers with a pound, legal bill.The probe was conducted by the People Directorate which is now at the heart of the ldquotransformation.The government confirmed under Freedom of Information this week that investigator Judith Mackinnon had been appointed by Director of People Nicola Richards.In an email to Ms Mackinnon last January, Ms Richards said: ldquoI have received this formal complaint from [redacted] and I am appointing you as the senior investigating officer. Would you be able to review this and get the investigation underway "I have thanked [redacted] and said that you will be in touch. Ms Mackinnon did not recuse herself.Separately, Mr Salmond last month appeared in court charged with two counts of attempted rape, nine of sexual assault, two of indecent assault and one of breach of the peace.He strongly denies any criminality.According to a government contract notice, ministers want their HR consultants to work with the People Directorate Improvement Programme team to ldquotest their vision.PA Consulting and the governmentrsquos HR bosses will look at ldquoHR services trends, and the lsquoart-of-the possiblersquo... emerging technologiesand HR lsquobest-practicersquo.In the contract notice, the governmentrsquos People Directorate said: ldquoOur aim is to become a lsquofit-for-purpose, modern, continuously improving HRthat makes the most of our people, processes and technology."Our services will offer an improved employee experience and will be value-for-money.rsquo We are seeking to appoint a Supplier who will work collaboratively with us to develop a strategy that will enable us to deliver services in the most optimal, economical and efficient way.The contract was not openly advertised, but awarded through the Quick Quote system meant for relatively minor contracts, where potential suppliers are approached directly.There were five bidders for the work, with the winning bid pound,.PA Consulting is now due to start the preliminary ldquodiscovery phase next Monday and finish by May .A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoWe operate a shared HR service for a number of government agencies."We are transforming the service to meet the needs of the customer base and to ensure the efficiency of our processes and technology.

title: key-sturgeon-adviser-urges-softest-possible-form-of-scottish-independence
story: Andrew Wilson, who chaired the SNPrsquos Growth Commission, also likened leaving the UK to a ldquoprocess rather than an event and said Scotland was on a ldquojourney without end.He said: ldquoIn the parlance of Brexit, we offer the softest of possible changes to the current arrangements, not the hardest. We recognise the level of integration and all the ties that have bound us for centuries. We create a  that can uny a majority for progress that stands a chance of winning and winning big.And he mocked Yes campaigners who saw independence as an abrupt radical change.ldquoSomewould rather move immediately and overnight to a Marxist revolutionary state. That is their right, but they wonrsquot win the chance to try, he said.:Former SNP MPs Indyref Tube plan branded unhingedThe comments will infuriate many within the wider Yes movement and reinforce the impression of the SNP hierarchy deliberating deflating expectations over Indyref.SNP MP Angus Macneil, former MP George Kerevan and former SNP leader Alex Salmond have all argued using the chaos over Brexit to press for a second referendum.But in an America TV interview last week, Ms Sturgeon said it was too soon for voters to come to an ldquoinformed decision and ldquocalm consideration was required instead.:Nicola Sturgeon: too soon to make informed decision on independenceMr Wilson, a former MSP who is now a corporate lobbyist, last year produced the SNPrsquos updated economic blueprint for an independent Scotland.It argued for a decade of restrained public spending after a Yes vote in order to halve Scotlandrsquos deficit, and the unofficial use of sterling instead of a new Scottish currency.His Growth Commission is now being chewed over by the SNP members.Writing in The National, Mr Wilson said Brexit meant there had been a fundamental change in circumstances since , and the last White Paper on independence.Brexit had also shown how long and dficult constitutional change could be.:SNP MP warns against bouncing country into IndyrefHe wrote: ldquoThe reality is that all change of such signicance in any organisation, let alone a major country, is a process rather than an event.ldquoTransitions take time as issues are worked through, new institutions built, agreements struck, and strategies put into place and then into action.ldquoA new Scottish White Paper will require to learn many lessons from , what has happened since and what is going so comprehensively wrong with Brexit.ldquoThe report of the Sustainable Growth Commission was designed to answer a brief to think through all of these points. It does not shirk the dficult questions and seeks to provide a sound framework and straight and honest answers. In doing so it seeks a prospectus that can uny a settled will behind Scotlandrsquos next step along our lsquojourney without endrsquo.:Alex Salmond takes swipe at SNP leadership over IndyrefMr Wilson said ldquoall of would love Rome to be built in a day, but the lesson of Brexit was that ldquohonesty, candour and realistic vision was the most likely to succeed.On currency, he said an independent Scotland would start bny keeping the pound, and only move to its own currency and Central Banksix key economic tests were passed.ldquoThis question could be re-examined every year in a report to Parliament, he said.In simple terms, passing the tests means it will be in the interests of our economy, trade, government and public finances and therefore services, citizens, jobs and employers to create a new Scottish currency.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins said:"The Nationalists are desperate for independence and they will do or say anything to get it.First their ill-fated White Paper was rejected by the people in the  referendum.ldquoThen Mr Wilsonrsquos growth commission blueprint for an austerity independence was rejected by his own SNP.Now theyrsquore onto their third attempt to woo voters by pretending that independence is not really independence at all.ldquoHospitals are in crisis, teachers are contemplating unprecedented strike action and roads are crumbling - the SNP has many more pressing matters to be focusing on than independence, whatever it is that means this week.LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton said: "With Brexit, the SNP have spent two years setting out the arguments against themselves.ldquoThey have slowly come round to the idea of a peoplersquos vote as it dawned on them that having close ties with our neighbours is a good thing and severing old unions is a tough and fruitless task.ldquoAndrew Wilson is advocating a soft-independence and a slow transition. Having written the Growth Commission report himself, he knows being out on our own will mean less money in the public purse and poorer public services."Thatrsquos not good for anyone in Scotland.Labour MSPJames Kelly added:"The author of the so-called Growth Commission can try and rebrand leaving the UK however he likes, but in reality his plans mean another decade of austerity for Scotland and an economic model that works for bigbusiness, not workers."Pamela Nash, chief executive of the pro-UK Scotland in Uniongroup, said:ldquoThere is no such thing as soft independence.ldquoIndependence would involve breaking up the most successful union the world has ever seen, building barriers between families, friends and neighbours.ldquoIt would ide our home market, jeopardising our economy, and lead to further and deeper austerity.ldquoWith the SNPrsquos proposal to rejoin the EU, an independent Scotland would have to sign up to the euro and there is the very real possibility of a hard border with the rest of the UK.ldquoVoters wonrsquot be fooled by this ndash the majority of people in Scotland know we are better off together and want Scotland to remain part of the UK, building a shared future based on economic prosperity.Separately, SNP ministers have been criticised for repeatedly refusing to say whether they have taken legal advice on holding a wildcat Catalan-style referendum on independence.The Scottish LibDems accused the government of ldquostonewalling on the issue after the top law officer refused to say whether he had been consulted on the matter.Responding to a request for details from MSP Mike Rumbles, the Lord Advocate James Wolffe QC said ldquoconvention meant it was inappropriate for him to comment.ldquoIt is however open to you to ask the Scottish Government what its position is, he said.But Mr Rumbles said he had already been given the brush-off by ministers.Theresa May has refused to grant Holyrood a so-called Section  order empowering it to hold another legally watertight referendum, leading to speculation about a wildcat vote, such as the one held in Catalonia in defiance of the Spanish government.Ms Sturgeon has also always said a Section  referendum, of the kind held in , is the gold standard, and has show no appetite for a Catalan-style vote.However Mr Rumbles said: ldquoThe Scottish Government are going to outrageous s to avoid telling the public what they are plotting behind closed doors. Ministers just shuffle excuses back and forward between themselves. Itrsquos not good enough.ldquoPeople have a right to know what their government is up to. Rather than stonewalling, government ministers mustto Parliament to confirm whether they are actively considering a wildcat independence referendum without a section  order.

title: royal-bank-rugbyforce-returns-to-attract-new-members-to-local-clubs
story: Now in its eleventh year, the nationwide rugby programme supports clubs by providing funding to help them attract new members, make improvements to facilities and to help clubs become more sustainable for the future.Three out of every four clubs in Scotland have benefited from Royal Bank RugbyForce support since  and the call is going out for more to apply and enjoy its support.At the home of Scottish rugby at BT Murrayfield, Menrsquos and Womenrsquos internationalists Grant Gilchrist, Megan Kennedy, Fraser Brown, Lana Skeldon and Jamie Ritchie, urged clubs up and down the country to think how they could benefit and become lsquoLoudest and Proudestrsquo for Scotland.Over  years, more than half a million pounds has been distributed amongst Scottish clubs and this yearrsquos campaign will see a celebration of the grassroots game with the Royal Bank RugbyForce weekend taking place on - August, where rugby clubs will host events for the local community and put their funding to use as they prepare their club for the new season.This yearrsquos #loudestandproudest theme comes as Royal Bank of Scotland encourages the whole of Scotland to join the rugby community and cheer on the national side. With the Guinness Six Nations underway and the Rugby World Cup on the horizon,  is set to be a thrilling year for Scottish Rugby.At BT Murrayfield, the Scotland internationalists met youth players Poppy Mellanbyand Ruari Watsonfrom Biggar RFC in South Lanarkshire and Evie Blairand Fraser Hayfrom Lasswade RFC in Midlothian.The potential rugby stars of tomorrow swapped the rugby ball for the microphone and put the international players through their paces with a series of one to one interviews, tackling them on subjects such as ldquowho is the loudest in the Scotland squad  and ldquowhat do you eat for breakfast .This yearrsquos  winning clubs will be awarded the ldquoloudest and proudest package which will see them receive pound, as well as a visit by one of the Scottish gamersquos biggest personalities on Royal Bank RugbyForce weekend. The chosen clubs will also receive full event support from Royal Bank of Scotland as they create a truly memorable day which places rugby at the heart of the community.Eight other lsquoStarrsquo clubs will receive pound, funding as well as rugby kit and appearances from Scotland rugby personalities who will be on hand during the weekend to roll up their sleeves and get involved with everything from coaching and development to DIY.An additional eight lsquoChampionrsquo clubs will secure pound, of financial support, with all other participating clubs in with the chance of receiving pound. All qualying clubs will receive digital support packs to host their own Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend.Scotland international and former Alloa RFC player Grant Gilchrist is one of the elite stars supporting the campaign this year and features in a series of short films encouraging clubs across Scotland to sign up to Royal Bank RugbyForce in .Grant said: ldquoSo many professional players take their first steps on a rugby field at a grassroots club. Without the tireless efforts of community clubs across Scotland, we wouldnrsquot have the talent and love for the game that we have today.ldquoSupporting your local team is so important. Royal Bank RugbyForce is an excellent initiative and itrsquos great to see so many local clubs in Scotland receiving the support they need to develop the next generation of Scottish rugby talent.Malcolm Buchanan, chairman, Royal Bank of Scotland, Scotland Board, said: ldquoWersquore very proud of our continued commitment to rugby in Scotland. The passion for the game remains strong and wersquore delighted to be able to play a part in supporting local rugby communities across the country with both financial and practical assistance.ldquoOur application process is designed with ease in mind and we would encourage clubs across the country to apply for this yearrsquos grants.  is set to be an important year for Scottish rugby and we want to help make sure that our grassroots clubs across the country can benefit too.Keith Wallace, Club President at Haddington RFC, one of the top two winning clubs in  said: ldquoRoyal Bank RugbyForce weekend was a fantastic occasion for our club as we took on the world record for the most players ever to take part in a game of touch rugby. With  players, aged from five to seventy-four, getting on the pitch, wersquore confident as we await ratication that we successfully kicked the previous record of  into touch.ldquoAside from the Guinness World Record attempt, we also used the grant money to contribute towards a recruitment drive to increase playing numbers at all levels and funding community engagement projects.ldquoWe would like to thank the Royal Bank of Scotland without whose support the event would not have been possible, in particular their many staff and advisors who helped massively on the day.

title: theresa-may-to-rule-out-no-deal-outcome-ahead-of-moment-of-truth-vote-on-february-27-says-cabinet-source
story: As MPs prepare for this eveningrsquos series of votes with Tory Brexiteers seemingly pulling back from a move to defeat the Government, the senior minister made clear Mrs May would come up with ldquoa form of words that would satisfy Parliament and her own Cabinet colleagues that she would not allow the UK to leave the EU without an agreement on March .Another Whitehall source predicted that the reassurance would come in the Government motion, which will be tabled in the hours before the February  debate and vote.Read more:SNP amendment to delay Brexit by at least three months selected for considerationHe suggested,the PMrsquos reassurance were as firm as colleagues hoped, then it would negate the need for people to vote for the Governmentrsquos main threat: the amendment set down by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper, which says thatthe PM has not got a deal through Parliament by March , then MPs would either have to vote to agree a no-deal Brexit or force the PM to seek an extension to the Article  process.ldquoFebruary  will be the moment of truth, declared the senior Government source. ldquoItrsquos when people will have to make a decision.This was an indirect reference to Cabinet colleagues like Amber Rudd, David Gauke and Greg Clark, who have dropped heavy hints that they could not be part of a government that allowed Britain to fall off a Brexit clf-edge without a deal and would resign.The revelation by the senior minister that Mrs May will, by February , effectively reject the possibility of a no-deal outcome will be meant to avert such a Cabinet rebellion.However, it is in direct conflict with the PMrsquos current position, which is, that the only way a no-deal Brexit can be ruled out is either by agreeing a deal or revoking Article .On Wednesday, her spokesman made clear: ldquoIf yoursquore asking me a question of does no-deal remain on the table, the answer is yes.Read more:Theresa May faces Valentines Day Commons humiliation as Tory Brexiteers poised to defeat Government motionBut a rejection of this position would also spark a major backlash from Tory Brexiteers, who believe keeping the option of a no-deal outcome on the table adds to Britainrsquos negotiating strength with Brussels.Of course, Mrs May is seeking to strike a new deal with Brussels ldquoas soon as possible and, theoretically, could secure an agreement with the EU by February . But most observers believe this to be highly unlikely and that the process will move towards the key vote at the end of the month.While like tonightrsquos vote, the one on February  will be a next-steps decision, which will not be legally binding, the Whitehall sources made clear, politically, it will be enormously important.One referred to it as a ldquosemi-meaningful vote. The meaningful vote on the PMrsquos fully-formed Plan B is not expected until March.As MPs began their latest debate on Brexit the prospect of defeat for Mrs May appeared to be receding after leading Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg suggested it was "highly unlikely" that Eurosceptic Tories would rebel after all.Members of the backbench Conservative European Research Group had threatened to vote down a Government motion, which they said effectively endorsed efforts to block a no-deal Brexit.But ministers warned that defeat for the PM would send the "wrong signal" to Brussels about the possibility of Parliament uniting behind the revised Withdrawal Agreement which Mrs May is seeking.Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, told potential rebels that Parliament was not an "internal debating society" and European negotiators would be watching to seeMPs were showing "consistency"."What we say is looked at and listened to by those that we are negotiating with," the Scot told BBC Radio s Today programme.Read more:BBC Question Time faces fresh row over claims it edited SNP retort to former UKIP candidate"They will be looking to see whether Parliament is showing consistency because in the debates and the votes we had recently there were two things: one was that Parliament said we dont want there to be no-deal and that we will sign up to the Prime Ministers dealwe are able to get changes to the Irish backstop."Our European partners will be watching our debate and listening today to seethey get the impression thatthey were to make those concessions, Parliament would definitely deliver on that."However, Steve Baker, the former Brexit minister, argued Conservatives should not be "associated with anything" that "seems to take no-deal off the table".Members of the ERG have been lobbying Downing Street for two days to amend the wording of Mrs Mays motion for the Valentines Day vote, which asks the Commons to "reiterate" its support for the approach approved in an earlier set of votes on January .MPs voted on that date to send Mrs May back to Brussels to seek an alternative to the "backstop" provisions in her EU Withdrawal Agreement which are intended to ensure the Irish border stays open after Brexit.But they also gave a majority the same day to a non-binding amendment calling on the Government to rule out a no-deal outcome.Some Eurosceptics would welcome no-deal, while others believe it must be kept as a weapon in the Governments armoury to ensure maximum leverage in extracting concessions from the EU.Speaking as Downing Street confirmed it would not amend the wording of the motion, backbencher Lee Rowley said: "The Government is essentially asking me to vote for something tonight - taking no- deal off the table - which isnt Government policy."We are all genuinely scratching our heads this morning asking what on earth they are doing. Instead of putting forward badly worded motions, the Government should be properly focusing on the Malthouse compromise - the one and only option which brings together Leavers and Remainers and, vitally, will command a majority in Parliament."ERG members declined to confirm whether there would be a rebellion or speculate on possible numbers involved.But Mr Rees-Mogg, the groups chairman, signalled three hours before voting was due to take place that the potential revolt was off.He told ITV News: "This is a secondary issue, rather than a primary one, and that is why it is highly unlikely people will be voting against this motion."Mrs Mays spokesman told reporters: "It is important that MPs support the Prime Minister today in order to send another clear message to Brussels on the need to address Parliaments concerns about the backstop, so we can leave on time with a deal on March ."John Bercow, the Commons Speaker, selected only three of the  amendments tabled for debate on the floor of the Commons.MPs are set to vote on a Labour amendment demanding that Mrs May hold a meaningful vote on her plan by February  or hand power to Parliament to decide the next steps.Also selected were an SNP amendment calling for a three-month extension to Brexit negotiations and a demand from pro-EU backbenchers led by Tory Anna Soubry for the publication of the latest official assessments of the likely economic impact of no deal.The latest showdown comes as Dutch PM Mark Rutte told the Financial Times the Netherlands was already benefiting from businesses relocating from a "diminished" Britain.But Mrs Mays spokesman insisted Number  "disagrees entirely" with Mr Ruttes stance, adding: "Employment is at a record high, exports are at a record high, companies are continuing to invest in the UK."Deloitte named the UK as Europes leading destination for foreign direct investment and London as the worlds top city for investment just last month."In a bid to keep lines open with EU leaders, Mrs May spoke to French President Emmanuel Macron and Romanian President Klaus Iohannis on Wednesday evening and is expected to make further phone calls over the course of Thursday.Peoples Vote protesters seeking a second EU referendum gathered outside Parliament to demonstrate against what they termed a "blindfold Brexit".And pro-Brexit campaigners from the Leave Means title: brexit-is-costing-britain-800m-a-week-or-80bn-since-eu-referendum-says-bank-of-england-policymaker
story: Gertjan Vlieghe, an external member of the central banks Monetary Policy Committee, also suggested that the shock of a no-deal orce could see interest rates slashed.He explained that, since the June  vote, two per cent had been shaved off GDP. This, he calculated, amounted to a loss of around pound million per week or poundbn a year."The analysis suggests that since the vote in June , we have lost two per cent of GDP relative to a scenario where there had been no signicant domestic economic events."That amounts to around poundbn per year or poundm per week of lost income for the country as a whole," Mr Vlieghe told an audience in London.The rate-setter pointed to a collapse in business investment into the UK, which had been stuck at zero while in G peers it had accelerated to six per cent a year."Firms have been saying in a number of surveys that the uncertainty about our future relationship with the EU is a source of concern for them that has been weighing on their investment spending as plans for expansion have, on average, been scaled back," Mr Vlieghe said.Labourrsquos Owen Smith described his figures as "eye-wateringly high" and warned that the NHS would suffer as a result."Damaging our economy makes addressing these problems harder, not easier. It means less money for the NHS and our other national priorities."This is a vivid and painful reminder that the promises of Brexit are not being - and cannot be ndash delivered," said the Welsh MP.Mr Vlieghe also warned that interest rates were more likely to be cut than hikedBritain crashed out of the EU without a deal."In the case of a no-deal scenario, I judge that an easing or an extended pause in monetary policy is more likely to be the appropriate policy response than a tightening," he said.His comments came with just over a month to go before Britains departure from the bloc on March  and with Parliament in a deadlock over Brexit, having rejected Theresa Mays initial deal.Last week, the Bank slashed its growth forecast for the economy and warned about the mounting risk of a recession in the event of a no-deal Brexit.On Wednesday, Mark Carney, the Banks governor, urged politicians to find a Brexit solution.Mr Vlieghe said a no-deal outcome without any transitional arrangements would lead to "economic disruption, which could possibly be severe".If a deal were reached, which included a transitional period, the pound would be likely to strengthen, which could lead to a tightening of monetary policy, he said.However, Mr Vlieghe noted how recent economic data, including inflation and GDP, pointed to a sluggish economy."Given that the data even in the past few weeks are suggesting the slowdown is continuing into the early part of this year, both domestically and globally, a lot needs to go right for this forecast to come to pass."I feel I can probably wait to see evidence of growth stabilising and inflation pressure rising before considering the next hike in Bank rate," he added.January inflation fell to a two-year low of . per cent and undershot the Banks .o per cent target, while recent GDP data revealed that economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter of .

title: farmers invited to getting greener grass event
story: Soil Association Scotland is inviting farmers to a free event with pasture expert Andre van Barneveld to find out how to prepare for the grazing season ahead.Feed stocks may be low due to the extreme weather conditions last year, but are there any management options that could help maximise spring pasture production Andre van Barneveld of Graise Consultancy says that although there is no silver bullet, there are things you can do to make the most of your pasture.“My approach revolves around rotational grazing,” he says.“Grazing stimulates grass growth, butyou have all the stock on all the grass all of the time it doesn’t work – the grass needs time to recover.”He says nitrogen fertiliser can be used in a minimal way to reduce costs as well as environmental impact.“There’s no point putting it on before grazing as nitrogen can’t stimulate grass growththere’s no growth there – you’d be wasting your money.”And there is attention to be paid long term to soil health.“Rotational grazing is better for soils in the long term because it improves root structure, which gives you better grass. It’s all linked in.“It’s about truly understanding the value of grass. If you value it, and you manage it through the season it can have a real impact on profitability.”Knowledge Transfer Specialist at QMS, Emily Grant, said: “Spring grass is hugely valuable to any livestock system, whether for lambing ewes, calving cows or growing youngstock. Making the most of it will help to not only keep feed and housing costs in check, but also set up high quality pastures for the rest of the grazing season.”The event will be held on Tuesday, February  atThainstone Agricultural Centre, Inverurie from –pm.It is free to farmers and land managers but booking is required.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"MasterChef stars John Torode and Spencer Matthews will attend this years Taste of Grampian"  MasterChef stars for Taste of Grampian viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"To book visit www.soilassociation.org, call Lyn on   or email lwhite@soilassociation.org.Come along and find how you can get more from your grazing season.

title: the top six questions people are asking google about brexit
story: Heres the answers to your questions:What is the new Brexit Party, which has been supported by Nigel Farage What is the new Brexit Party and how do I join The Brexit Party was launched with the support of ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage in January and recognised as an official party at the beginning of February . It is a pro-Brexit party. Farage has said he will stand as an MEP under the partythe UK does not leave the EU orArticle  is extended. An official website is coming soon, and you should be able to sign up then, but in the meantime you can search for Brexit Party UK on Facebook.Will my passport be valid after Brexit Theres no need to do anything until your current passport is ready for renewal. British passports will change after we leave the EU, with blue and gold passports making afrom October , but youll still be able to travel on your old burgundy passport until it runs out. If theres a no deal Brexit, youll need to have at least six months left on your passport to travel to an EU country. If you renewed your passport before it expired, then any extra months wont count either - your passport should not be any older than nine years and six months when you travel. What is ERG This stands for the European Research Group, which is a group of pro-Brexit Conservative MPs chaired by Jacob-Res Mogg. It is lobbying on issues surrounding Brexit. The group was in the news as it is expected to rebel against todays House of Commons motion which asks MPs to reiterate its support for renegotiating the controversial Irish backstop.Read more: Will UK workers lose their rights and entitlements after Brexit Will EHIC still be valid At the minute,we fall sick or get injured while visiting the EU, then we can access the same free or discounted medical care that is available to residents of that country. The European Health Insurance Cardproves your eligibility. Regardless of the deal reached, the government will need to renegotiate the reciprocal healthcare arrangements. At the minute, a bill called HealthcareBill is being passed through Parliament to help reach such an arrangement. It is important as the scheme provides healthcare for an estimated , UK expats living in the EU as well as  million UK residents who travel abroad to EEA countries each year Until a new initiative is in place, you should check what the agreement is with the country youre visiting as EHIC may not be valid. Make sure you have travel insurance too .Will I need a visa for my holiday Not for short-term stays for holidays or business purposes. This is providing the UK offers the same deal for EU citizens who want to visit us. We will, however, have to to pay a fee to visit Europe after Brexit. From , youll need to fill in a ETIAS application form so other countries can check youre not a security threat. This is similar to the US ESTA scheme. title: understanding the transition period in the case of a no deal brexit
story: No -there is no deal theres no transition period. What happens to the transition period with an no deal Brexit The transition period was set up as part of the EU Withdrawal Agreement. If this goes ahead, then the transition period would run from March  when we officially leave the EU up until December  .During this period, the UK would trade with the EU in the same way we do now while the two parties agree a new and permanent relationship. It would help businesses, iniduals and the government to prepare for new arrangements and minimise the disruption from any changes. If the withdrawal is rejected, then this is what is being called a no deal Brexit, and there will be no transition period. If this happens, all changes would happen immediately on March .Were getting to the bottom of all your Brexit-related questions. title: uryside park secures european funding
story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. It’s also about learning from others and exploring practice further afield and deciding what to stop doing, what we should be doing more of and what we should start doing.Delegates will take part in a range of workshops and hear from keynote speaker Dave Clubb. Dave who hails from Shetland is a Social Worker with  years experience in dferent positions within the Shetland Islands Council before working for five years on a freelance basis and becoming a foster carer. vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: team appointed for 4 5m north isles landscape partnership scheme
story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
